comments:
Unfortunately I can't be very explicit about the nature of the following issue as it seems to inherently prevent me from digging into it.
What I discovered is that any kind of editor kind of starves in a wait state as soon as I try to open it. ViewParts seem to work nicely. I can't further investigate right now what causes this situation, because debugging is affected as well.
I must say that I have this problem since I changed to openSUSE 10.2 which has Xorg 7.2 as a major change.
The phenomenum does not occur in the 3.2 eclipse release though.
Can you get a stack trace to show us?

The problem lies somewhere within libswt-pi-gtk* when

public static final native void _gtk_enumerate_printers(int /*long*/ func, int /*long*/data, int /*long*/ destroy, boolean wait);

in class OS (from org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.x86) is called. It never returns (it doesn't raise an error either).

The parameters are:
func	-1549097609	
data	0	
destroy	0	
wait	true	


My eclipse loads the following libraries:

changed severity. Maybe now somebody from SWT feels encouraged to dig his nose into this. Eclipse is completely unusable if this isn't solved.
the same happens here (openSUSE 10.2, kde, sun-jdk 1.6)

I am having the same problem after updating to OpenSuSE 10.2.

(In reply to comment #6)
> I am having the same problem after updating to OpenSuSE 10.2. 
> 
> When opening a text editor the starvation can also be observed. My .log shows
> the following error (NullPointerException):

[ Stacktrace ]

Alexander, I think the NullPointerException is thrown, as you finally decide to close/abort Eclipse.  By the way, I'm also using openSUSE 10.2 and this bug occurs here too.  May it be more appropriate to report this on Novell's Bugzilla pages?
The same happens here. Gentoo (Gnome, sun-jdk1.5), so I don't believe it's related only to OpenSUSE

To those of you on this bug who are still experiencing this problem, can you please answer a couple of quesions for me:

1) Do you have any printers installed (using CUPS), and if so, can you print to them from another application?

2) What version of GTK are you using? (rpm -q gtk2)

Please also read bug 153936, and see if making any of the changes mentioned there (change to KDE if you are using Gnome, upgrade to a newer 2.10.x gtk, update your CUPS install, ...) make any difference for you.
The gtk2-2.10.6-24.2 from suse build service seems to have solved the issue, at least for me.
Having updated to gtk2-2.10.6-24.2 has solved the problem for me, too.

Carolyn, do you believe that this issue is fixed?  Do we need to put in a GTK version check and enable printing only on "good" versions of GTK?  It seems that I keep asking this question.  Possibly, you've done this already and I keep forgetting?

Have a workaround for gtk_enumerate_printers - will post details in Bug 153936.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 153936 ***
*** Bug 183952 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
